title: Andres Oper
text:
Andres Oper (born 7 November 1977) is an Estonian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Coach%20%28sport%29">coach</a> and former professional <a href="football%20player">player</a>. He is currently an assistant manager of <a href="FC%20Levadia%20Tallinn">FC Levadia Tallinn</a>.
Oper played as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a> for <a href="FC%20Lelle">Lelle</a>, <a href="FC%20Flora">Flora</a>, <a href="JK%20Tervis%20P%C3%A4rnu">Tervis Pärnu</a>, <a href="AaB%20Fodbold">AaB</a>, <a href="FC%20Torpedo%20Moscow">Torpedo Moscow</a>, <a href="Roda%20JC%20Kerkrade">Roda JC</a>, <a href="Shanghai%20Shenhua%20F.C.">Shanghai Shenhua</a>, <a href="ADO%20Den%20Haag">ADO Den Haag</a>, <a href="AEK%20Larnaca%20F.C.">AEK Larnaca</a>, <a href="Nea%20Salamis%20Famagusta%20FC">Nea Salamina</a> and the <a href="Estonia%20national%20football%20team">Estonia national team</a>. With 38 goals in 134 appearances, Oper is Estonia's all-time record goalscorer. Oper was named <a href="Estonian%20Footballer%20of%20the%20Year">Estonian Footballer of the Year</a> three times, in 1999, 2002 and 2005, and won the <a href="Estonian%20Silverball">Estonian Silverball</a> award twice, in 2001 and 2005.
Early life.
Oper was born in <a href="Tallinn">Tallinn</a>. He graduated from the Tallinn Secondary School No. 37. He started playing football with Tallinna Jalgpallikool () under Aivar Tiidus, before moving to Taivo Uibo's Uibo Poisid and then LMSK/Pantrid, coached by <a href="Aavo%20Sarap">Aavo Sarap</a>.
Club career.
Flora.
In 1995, Oper signed for <a href="FC%20Flora">Flora</a>. He won his first <a href="Meistriliiga">Meistriliiga</a> title in the <a href="1994%E2%80%9395%20Meistriliiga">1994–95 season</a>. Oper soon became a first team regular and one of the team's leading goalscorers. He won two more league titles in the <a href="1997%E2%80%9398%20Meistriliiga">1997–98</a> and the <a href="1998%20Meistriliiga">1998 season</a>s, as well as the <a href="1997%E2%80%9398%20Estonian%20Cup">1997–98 Estonian Cup</a> and the <a href="Estonian%20Supercup">Estonian Supercup</a> in 1998.
AaB.
On 2 July 1999, Oper signed for <a href="Danish%20Superliga">Danish Superliga</a> champions <a href="AaB%20Fodbold">AaB</a>, on a five-year contract for a transfer fee of $1 million (EEK 15 million).
Torpedo Moscow.
On 10 July 2003, Oper signed a two-year contract with <a href="Russian%20Premier%20League">Russian Premier League</a> club <a href="FC%20Torpedo%20Moscow">Torpedo Moscow</a>. Often inconsistent in Russia, scoring 8 goals in 53 appearances, Oper was placed on the transfer list after he suffered an injury to his right foot. In 2005, he was linked with a transfer to Sunderland in England, but the contract was never signed.
Roda JC.
On 31 August 2005, Oper signed a one-year contract with Dutch <a href="Eredivisie">Eredivisie</a> club <a href="Roda%20JC%20Kerkrade">Roda JC</a> for an undisclosed fee. He scored his first Eredivisie goal on 1 October 2005, in a 3–2 win against <a href="Vitesse%20Arnhem">Vitesse Arnhem</a>. Oper finished the <a href="2005%E2%80%9306%20Eredivisie">2005–06 Eredivisie</a> season as the team's joint top scorer alongside <a href="Simon%20Cziommer">Simon Cziommer</a> with 8 goals and signed a contract extension for two more seasons. He was the team's top scorer in the <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20Eredivisie">2006–07 Eredivisie</a> season, scoring 12 goals in the league and 1 in the play-offs. On 16 May 2007, he signed another contract extension with Roda JC until summer 2009.
Shanghai Shenhua.
On 19 July 2009, Oper signed a half-year contract with <a href="Chinese%20Super%20League">Chinese Super League</a> club <a href="Shanghai%20Shenhua%20F.C.">Shanghai Shenhua</a>. He made his debut for the club on 2 August 2009, in an away match against <a href="Jiangsu%20Sainty%20F.C.">Jiangsu Sainty</a>. However, he suffered an injury and eventually terminated his contract with the club.
ADO Den Haag.
After an unsuccessful spell in China, Oper returned to the Netherlands and on 21 January 2010, he signed a half-year contract with an option for another year with <a href="ADO%20Den%20Haag">ADO Den Haag</a>. He made his debut for the club on 13 February 2010 in a home match against <a href="Willem%20II%20%28football%20club%29">Willem II</a>. Oper scored his first goal for ADO Den Haag on 18 April 2010, in a 4–0 win against <a href="RKC%20Waalwijk">RKC Waalwijk</a>. His contract extension stalled due to negotiations over personal terms, eventually no agreement was settled and the extension was cancelled. The contract expired in summer.
AEK Larnaca.
On 9 September 2010, Oper signed a one-year contract with <a href="Cypriot%20First%20Division">Cypriot First Division</a> club <a href="AEK%20Larnaca%20F.C.">AEK Larnaca</a>. He scored on his debut against <a href="Ethnikos%20Achna%20FC">Ethnikos Achna</a>.
Nea Salamina.
In January 2012, Oper joined <a href="Cypriot%20First%20Division">Cypriot First Division</a> club <a href="Nea%20Salamis%20Famagusta%20FC">Nea Salamina</a>. He scored his first goal for the club on 3 March in a 2–0 win against <a href="Enosis%20Neon%20Paralimni%20FC">Enosis Neon Paralimni</a>.
International career.
Oper made his international debut for the <a href="Estonia%20national%20football%20team">Estonia national football team</a> on 19 May 1995, in a 0–2 <a href="1995%20Baltic%20Cup">1995 Baltic Cup</a> defeat against <a href="Latvia%20national%20football%20team">Latvia</a>. He scored his first goal for Estonia on 8 June 1997, in a 2–3 <a href="1998%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28UEFA%29">1998 FIFA World Cup qualification</a> loss against <a href="Sweden%20national%20football%20team">Sweden</a>. He won the <a href="Estonian%20Silverball">Estonian Silverball</a> award twice, in 2001 and 2005. On 2 September 2006, Oper played his <a href="List%20of%20men%27s%20footballers%20with%20100%20or%20more%20international%20caps">100th</a> match for Estonia, a 0–1 <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202008%20qualifying">UEFA Euro 2008 qualifying</a> defeat against <a href="Israel%20national%20football%20team">Israel</a>. He ended his international career with a <a href="testimonial%20match">testimonial match</a> on 26 May 2014, after a 1–1 friendly draw against <a href="Gibraltar%20national%20football%20team">Gibraltar</a> at <a href="A.%20Le%20Coq%20Arena">A. Le Coq Arena</a>. With 38 goals in 134 international appearances, Oper is Estonia's all-time record goalscorer. He played for the <a href="Estonia%20national%20football%20team">Estonia national team</a> for eighteen years in a row.
